image.altText: Firefighters stand near blackened ground as flames move up a hill near a property.

items.synopsis: Firefighters were kept busy overnight with dozens of bushfire warnings across southern Queensland and northern New South Wales with more property losses confirmed. Follow live

title.children: Number of homes lost in Queensland surpasses 2019 Black Summer bushfire season with more property losses confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast: "I can confirm that there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great. "The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind. "Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected. "And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment. "But, you know, we didn't lose any people and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Four more houses confirmed lost in Wallangarra overnight

children.content: (ABC News)
Southern Downs Mayor Vic Pennisi has just spoken to News Breakfast:
"I can confirm that
there's been four homes lost in Wallangarra
. However, the danger at this point in time has passed. People are beginning to move back into their homes which is great.

"The fires when through very, very quickly from when the evacuation was called to when the fire got there. In the hills, they just move at a great pace of knots, especially when they're fanned with the wind.
"Of course, the loss of any property would be devastating for those residents who have been affected.

"And you know, my heart goes out to those people who have lost their properties. You know that your home is your castle. You've got so many family memories in there. You know, kids and photos and all those sorts of things. So I can't begin to imagine what those people who have lost their homes are going through at the moment.
"But, you know,
we didn't lose any people
and you know, that's our primary concern is to make sure that our people are as safe as possible. And our Fire and Emergency Services have done a wonderful job."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kirsten Webster and Danielle Mahe The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland. Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am on Wednesday, following reports a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday reignited. Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions. Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly. "We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said. "It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished. Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating. "I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires." Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities believe arsonist is active in Gold Coast hinterland

children.content: Reporting by Kirsten Webster and Danielle Mahe
The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland.
Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am
on Wednesday, following reports
a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday
reignited.
Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions.
Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly.
"We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said.
"It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said
A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished.
Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating.

"I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires."
Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season. As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019. Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council, said the loss had had a huge impact on the community. "The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said. "Obviously housing will be our greatest need."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More homes lost in Qld than in 2019 Black Summer

children.content: The loss of homes has had a huge impact on Tara.
(ABC News: Chris Gillette)
The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season.

As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019.
Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council,
said the loss had had a huge impact on the community.
"The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said.
"Obviously housing will be our greatest need."

items.synopsis: Hamas's tunnels under Gaza are a prime target for Israel as it expands its ground offensive in the north of the enclave after three weeks of aerial bombardment.

title.children: Ground-level clashes intensify as Israeli military confirms deadly strikes on Gaza refugee camp

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, a spokesperson for the Israeli Defense Force (IDF) doubled down on their claim that their strike on the Jabalia refugee camp in Northern Gaza was targeting a legitimate combat zone. Colonel Jonathan Conricus, IDF's international spokesperson, confirmed they were behind a deadly air strike, which they claim has killed a top Hamas commander. "There was no strike on a refugee camp," he told ABC's Patricia Karvelas. "We targeted a Hamas battalion commander, a very important combatant who was leading combat operations against us. "He was hiding together with many of his terrorists, his combatants in a tunnel complex underneath civilian houses, underneath the street." Earlier, we reported that an IDF statement said the strike on Jabalia, Gaza's largest refugee camp, had killed Ibrahim Biari. Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem has denied any senior commander was there and called the claim an Israeli pretext for killing civilians. "I can confirm that he has been killed, and so have many terrorists. That was the aim of what we have done," Colonel Conricus told the ABC. "I understand that there are reports of civilian casualties. I want to emphasise the civilians are not our targets – we focus on Hamas. "And it is because of Hamas practices of using women and children and civilians as their human shields that there are casualties." The Hamas-run health ministry and a hospital director say at least 50 civilians were also killed. UN Special Rapporteur for the Palestinian Territories, Francesca Albanese, responded directly to the claim, saying the Israeli strike on Jabalia could constitute a crime against humanity. "A refugee camp inhabited by 400 cannot be a legitimate military target, and this cannot be justified. If it is it might be an extermination, which constituted a crime against humanity under international law," she told RN Breakfast. Follow the link below to listen to the interview:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF says it targeted a Hamas 'battalion commander', UN says refugee camp is 'not a legitimate military target'

featuredLink.title: 'This is a combat zone': IDF confirms refugee camp air strike - ABC listen

children.content: Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, a spokesperson for the Israeli Defense Force (IDF) doubled down on their claim that their strike on the Jabalia refugee camp in Northern Gaza was targeting a legitimate combat zone.
Colonel Jonathan Conricus, IDF's international spokesperson,
confirmed they were behind a deadly air strike, which they claim has killed a top Hamas commander.
"There was no strike on a refugee camp," he told ABC's Patricia Karvelas.
"We targeted a Hamas battalion commander, a very important combatant who was leading combat operations against us.
"He was hiding together with many of his terrorists, his combatants in a tunnel complex underneath civilian houses, underneath the street."
Earlier, we reported that an IDF statement said the strike on Jabalia, Gaza's largest refugee camp, had killed Ibrahim Biari.
Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem has denied any senior commander was there and called the claim an Israeli pretext for killing civilians.
"I can confirm that he has been killed, and so have many terrorists. That was the aim of what we have done," Colonel Conricus told the ABC.
"I understand that there are reports of civilian casualties. I want to emphasise the civilians are not our targets – we focus on Hamas.
"And it is because of Hamas practices of using women and children and civilians as their human shields that there are casualties."
The Hamas-run health ministry and a hospital director say at least 50 civilians were also killed.
UN Special Rapporteur for the Palestinian Territories, Francesca Albanese, responded directly to the claim, saying the Israeli strike on Jabalia could constitute a crime against humanity.

"A refugee camp inhabited by 400 cannot be a legitimate military target, and this cannot be justified. If it is it might be an extermination, which constituted a crime against humanity under international law," she told RN Breakfast.
Follow the link below to listen to the interview:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rafah border crossing will be opened on Wednesday for a number of Palestinians who were injured in Gaza to complete their treatment in Egyptian hospitals, Egyptian medical and security sources said. It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this. "We are intensely focused on getting the gate open. "We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah crossing to be opened for injured Gazans to complete treatment in Egypt

children.content: The
Rafah border crossing
will be opened on Wednesday for a number of
Palestinians who were injured in Gaza
to complete their treatment in
Egyptian hospitals
, Egyptian medical and security sources said.
It comes shortly after the United States said it was "intensely focused" on getting the Rafah crossing opened for Americans and foreigners to leave Gaza.
State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller added Washington had made good progress on this.
"We are intensely focused on getting the gate open.
"We have made good progress on this even in the past few hours and hope to keep making progress to get those American citizens out," Miller said.
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian government 10-year bonds have been on a run over the past couple of weeks, as expectations of at least one more Reserve Bank interest rate rise mount. According to Refinitiv data, markets are now pricing about a two-thirds chance of the RBA hiking next Tuesday. Bloomberg data has those odds closer to 56% for a rate hike, but also indicates that markets have almost fully priced in two more hikes by the middle of next year to take the cash rate to 4.6%, not just one and done. Expectations of longer term risk free interest rates are even higher, with the Australian 10-year bond closing in on passing 5% for the first time since 2011. The Australian 10-year bond (white line) has now punched above the US benchmark rate (blue line), as local rate expectations are now higher than those for further Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Fed is currently meeting, with the outcome to be announced tomorrow morning Australian time. The current target Fed funds rate in the US is 5.25-5.5%. The market is pricing in almost no chance of a rate rise at this meeting, and just 25% at the December meeting. It's also pricing in a slim chance of rate cuts as early as March and the likelihood of rate cuts by July next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian 10-year bond yields overtake US, head towards 5%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Washington-based International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Reserve Bank to lift interest rates further. Using its annual report into the Australian economy, the fund said that although inflation was easing, it was still too high. The RBA board meets next Tuesday, with most economists and financial markets forecasting that the cash rate will be increased by 0.25 per cent to a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent. The fund said while fiscal policy was working in line with monetary policy, higher interest rates would be necessary to bring down inflation, which has eased to 5.4 per cent but remains well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target band. "While headline inflation has peaked, its decline is slow and core inflation remains sticky," the IMF said in a statement. "The authorities have implemented several policy measures which have significantly contributed to stabilizing the economy and reducing inflation, but staff assess that more is needed to bring inflation back to target and keep inflation expectations anchored. "Continued coordination between fiscal and monetary policy is key to achieving a soft landing, while alleviating the impact of policy tightening on vulnerable households." It called on the federal government and state and territory governments to "implement public investment projects at a more measured and coordinated pace, given supply constraints, to alleviate inflationary pressures and support the RBA's disinflation efforts". "Otherwise, interest rates would have to be even higher, putting the burden of adjustment disproportionately on mortgage holders," it said. Building on recent reforms, it said policymakers should continue their efforts to address climate change and need to do more to boost productivity.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IMF says Australia needs higher interest rates

children.content: The Washington-based International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Reserve Bank to lift interest rates further.
Using its annual report into the Australian economy, the fund said that although inflation was easing, it was still too high.
The RBA board meets next Tuesday, with most economists and financial markets forecasting that the cash rate will be increased by 0.25 per cent to a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent.

The fund said while fiscal policy was working in line with monetary policy, higher interest rates would be necessary to bring down inflation, which has eased to 5.4 per cent but remains well above the RBA's 2 to 3 per cent target band.
"While headline inflation has peaked, its decline is slow and core inflation remains sticky," the IMF said in a statement.
The IMF says Australia needs to keep raising rates
(Jonathan Ernst: Reuters)

"The authorities have implemented several policy measures which have significantly contributed to stabilizing the economy and reducing inflation, but staff assess that more is needed to bring inflation back to target and keep inflation expectations anchored.
"Continued coordination between fiscal and monetary policy is key to achieving a soft landing, while alleviating the impact of policy tightening on vulnerable households."

It called on the federal government and state and territory governments to "implement public investment projects at a more measured and coordinated pace, given supply constraints, to alleviate inflationary pressures and support the RBA's disinflation efforts".
"Otherwise, interest rates would have to be even higher, putting the burden of adjustment disproportionately on mortgage holders," it said.
Building on recent reforms, it said policymakers should continue their efforts to address climate change and need to do more to boost productivity.
